text: HEARING ON SB 445

text: Opening Statement by Sponsor:
label: HH2

text: SENATOR CHARLES SWYSGOOD, SD 17, Dillon, stated SB 445 was
label: HH2

text: brought to the committee to address concerns the community had
label: BODY

text: with conditions on two rivers in his district.  He said there has
label: BODY

text: been a lot of discussion about the subject and there is a feeling
label: BODY

text: that something has to be done.  He commented that SB 445 limits
label: BODY

text: the number of launches for outfitters on the Beaverhead and Big
label: BODY

text: Hole Rivers.  The bill also limits the use to weekdays only for
label: BODY

text: outfitters and weekends for the general public fishing.  He said
label: BODY

text: the bill also has a section directing the Department of Fish
label: BODY

text: Wildlife and Parks to allow the Big Hole Watershed Committee and
label: BODY

text: the Beaverhead County Consensus Forum to develop further plans
label: BODY

text: for recreational uses of the two rivers.
label: BODY

text: Proponents' Testimony:
label: HH2

text: {Tape : 1; Side : A; Approx. Time Counter : 5.3}
label: HH2

text: REPRESENTATIVE BILL TASH, HD 34, Dillon, said the problems have
label: HH2

text: been accumulating on the two rivers.  He stated the legislation
label: BODY

text: is needed very much in order to appropriately regulate these
label: BODY

text: waters to the point of where the resident fishers are not
label: BODY

text: canceled out.
label: BODY

text: Robin Cunningham, Fishing Outfitters Assoc. of MT, said the
label: HH2

text: association supports SB 445 and proposed amendments.  The
label: BODY

text: SENATE COMMITTEE ON FISH AND GAME
label: BODY

text: February 16, 1999
label: BODY

text: PAGE 3 of 21
label: BODY

text: 990216FIS_Sm1.wpd
label: BODY

text: association recognizes the problems on these rivers.  He stated
label: BODY

text: outfitters are typically held to a higher standard.  He discussed
label: BODY

text: the rules of etiquette for the rivers.  He said outfitters must
label: BODY

text: be willing to regulate themselves.  He described the three main
label: BODY

text: points of the bill.  He said the proposed amendments are directed
label: BODY

text: toward the last two main points.  He entered and discussed the
label: BODY

text: amendments, EXHIBIT(fis38a01).
label: BODY

text: Randy Smith, Big Hole Watershed Committee, discussed how the Big
label: HH2

text: Hole Watershed Committee came about and who the members are.  He
label: BODY

text: described the issues which they worked on.  He stated they
label: BODY

text: support the bill to get the process started before there is a
label: BODY

text: worse problem that will require immediate action by the FWP.
label: BODY

text: Steve Luebeck, George Grant Chapter of Trout Unlimited, provided
label: HH2

text: written testimony, EXHIBIT(fis38a02).
label: BODY

text: Vince Fischer, SkyLine Sportsman, stated they think the bill is
label: HH2

text: reasonable and needed.  He hopes the committee will support the
label: BODY

text: bill particularly with the amendments that have been presented.
label: BODY

text: Jim Hagenbarth, Big Hole Watershed Committee, stated the
label: HH2

text: committee is very concerned about the pressure on the Big Hole
label: BODY

text: River and its quality.  He stated no matter how the committee
label: BODY

text: decides to limit the pressure on the rivers, it must not be
label: BODY

text: greater than it historically was.  He discussed a section of the
label: BODY

text: river from Melrose down and said if that piece is not regulated
label: BODY

text: late in the year there will be problems.
label: BODY

text: Jerry Kustich, Lewis & Clark Chapter of Trout Unlimited, stated
label: HH2

text: they support the bill.  He commented if the amendments are
label: BODY

text: satisfactory with the outfitting industry and all interested
label: BODY

text: parties, they will be interested in backing the legislation.  He
label: BODY

text: stated if they gain this and lose access on SB 418, then SB 445
label: BODY

text: will make no sense.
label: BODY

text: Robbie Garrett, Beaverhead County Forum, provided written
label: HH2

text: testimony, EXHIBIT(fis38a03) and pamphlet, EXHIBIT(fis38a04).
label: BODY

text: Allen Schallenberger, Citizen from Sheridan, asked to withdraw a
label: HH2

text: letter he sent because he now supports the bill with amendments.
label: BODY

text: Monty Hankinson, Big Hole/Beaverhead Outfitters and Guides
label: HH2

text: Assoc., stated his main concern is the Beaverhead River.  He said
label: HH1

text: the river cannot handle the pressure it is taking.
label: BODY

text: Bill Allen, Beaverhead Outdoors Association, stated the
label: HH2

text: association is in favor of SB 445.
label: BODY

text: SENATE COMMITTEE ON FISH AND GAME
label: BODY

text: February 16, 1999
label: BODY

text: PAGE 4 of 21
label: BODY

text: 990216FIS_Sm1.wpd
label: BODY

text: Pat Graham, Fish Wildlife and Parks, entered written testimony,
label: HH2

text: EXHIBIT(fis38a05).
label: HH1

text: Paul Roos, Outfitter, said he supports SB 445.  He commented on
label: HH2

text: the cut off date of January 1, 1999 and the Smith River process.
label: BODY

text: He stated the amendment proposing the two launch concepts is good
label: BODY

text: and also thinks the concept of trying to control lateral
label: BODY

text: expansion of outfitters of a total season is good.  He said the
label: BODY

text: state needs a bill that deals with the whole issue state-wide.
label: BODY

text: {Tape : 1; Side : A; Approx. Time Counter : 31.9}
label: HH2

text: Stuart Decker, Big Hole River Foundation, said the foundation is
label: HH2

text: in support of the bill as long as the amendments seek to make it
label: BODY

text: a more inclusive process for consensus building.
label: BODY

text: Darrell Baker, Anaconda Sportsmen, stated they support SB 445
label: HH2

text: with amendments.
label: BODY

text: Garth Haogland, Beaverhead County Commission, stated the
label: HH2

text: commission believes SB 445 is the answer or the start of answers
label: BODY

text: to addressing the issues that have occurred through recreation
label: BODY

text: use of the rivers that flow through the county.
label: BODY

text: {Tape : 1; Side : A; Approx. Time Counter : 33.4}
label: HH2

text: Opponents' Testimony:
label: HH2

text: David Dittloff, MT Wildlife Federation, provided written
label: HH2

text: testimony, EXHIBIT(fis38a06) and proposed amendments,
label: BODY

text: EXHIBIT(fis38a07) and a outline of why they oppose SB 445,
label: HH1

text: EXHIBIT(fis38a08).
label: HH1

text: Jim McDermand, Medicine River Canoe Club, stated their concern is
label: HH2

text: the Beaverhead and Big Hole Rivers which are Montana rivers and
label: BODY

text: all Montanans use them.  He said Montana desperately needs a
label: BODY

text: state-wide river management bill to address over crowding and
label: BODY

text: social conflict among users, but any plan should have input from
label: BODY

text: all users, not just the local people.  He said if the club's
label: BODY

text: concerns are addressed through the amendments offered, then they
label: BODY

text: would have no problem excepting SB 445 with amendments.
label: BODY

text: {Tape : 1; Side : A; Approx. Time Counter : 36.7}
label: HH2

text: Questions from Committee Members and Responses:
label: HH2

text: SENATOR DOHERTY referred about the amendments which proposed the
label: HH2

text: outfitters would be limited in the number of launches to two
label: BODY

text: boats per state or federal river access per day.  He asked if
label: BODY

text: SENATE COMMITTEE ON FISH AND GAME
label: BODY

text: February 16, 1999
label: BODY

text: PAGE 5 of 21
label: BODY

text: 990216FIS_Sm1.wpd
label: BODY

text: that is intended to mean all outfitters or just one outfitter
label: BODY

text: will limit himself to two launches per access site.  Robin
label: BODY

text: Cunningham replied the population of outfitters that are allowed
label: HH1

text: to participate on these rivers according to their operation plan
label: BODY

text: would be included in the population who must limit them
label: BODY

text: individually to two boats per site per day.  He said outfitters
label: BODY

text: could launch no more than two craft per site.  SENATOR DOHERTY
label: BODY

text: asked if that was all outfitters or just each individual
label: BODY

text: outfitter is limited to two launches per site per day.  Robin
label: BODY

text: Cunningham responded yes, each outfitter is limited to two.
label: HH1

text: SENATOR DOHERTY asked how many sites are on the river that they
label: HH1

text: are talking about that an outfitter would be able to launch from.
label: BODY

text: Robin Cunningham stated on the Big Hole River there are probably
label: HH1

text: 15 sites yielding 30 craft per outfitter per day.
label: BODY

text: SENATOR DOHERTY asked how many outfitters are licensed to do
label: HH2

text: business on the Big Hole and how many launches are they being
label: BODY

text: limited to compared to what is going on already.  Pat Graham
label: BODY

text: replied the department does not license outfitters so he could
label: BODY

text: not give the figures.  SENATOR DOHERTY asked if he knows how many
label: BODY

text: crafts are being launched per day during the season.  Pat Graham
label: BODY

text: answered somewhere between 7-8% of the use is outfitted.  He said
label: BODY

text: he could not translate that into an actual use figure but could
label: BODY

text: get that information.
label: BODY

text: SENATOR DOHERTY said what he is was getting at is how much are
label: HH2

text: they really limiting, and if they are really limiting anything at
label: BODY

text: all.  Pat Graham replied he understands his point but doesn't
label: BODY

text: have the information to tell him.
label: BODY

text: SENATOR WELLS stated the amendment Mr. Cunningham proposed,
label: HH2

text: limits the access for the areas from Jerry Creek down to Salmon
label: BODY

text: Fly.  He asked how much of the river is being left for the
label: BODY

text: sportsman fisherman.  Robin Cunningham said it is more
label: BODY

text: appropriate for a local outfitter to answer the question.  Stuart
label: BODY

text: Decker replied Jerry Creek to Melrose represents about 35-40
label: HH1

text: miles with 5 access sites.  He said of the section of the river
label: BODY

text: that is considered fishable represents the gut of the best and
label: BODY

text: has special regulations in place.  Historically, this is where
label: BODY

text: most of people give their attention when they go fishing.  That
label: BODY

text: is where the most pressure is.  He said Jerry Creek down to
label: BODY

text: Melrose represents probably 70% of the traffic any given day.
label: BODY

text: SENATOR WELLS asked about the section on the Beaverhead River
label: HH2

text: from Clark Canyon to Hannonberry.  Monty Hankinson stated on the
label: BODY

text: Beaverhead from the dam to Hannonberry there are three major
label: BODY

text: accesses which cover the first 5-6 miles of the river.  SENATOR
label: BODY

text: WELLS asked what percentage is the first 5-6 miles, 50% of the
label: HH1

text: SENATE COMMITTEE ON FISH AND GAME
label: BODY

text: February 16, 1999
label: BODY

text: PAGE 6 of 21
label: BODY

text: 990216FIS_Sm1.wpd
label: BODY

text: river or is it a good fishing area.  Monty Hankinson replied that
label: BODY

text: is the most popular area.  He said on any tail water, the first
label: BODY

text: few miles below the dam are always the top fishing and most
label: BODY

text: popular area.
label: BODY

text: SENATOR TAYLOR asked how many outfitters are on the river on a
label: HH2

text: given day and how many boats go down the river.  Stuart Decker
label: BODY

text: said that is a moving target.  He asked Senator Taylor if he is
label: BODY

text: asking for outfitters who reside directly in the area or
label: BODY

text: outfitters who use it habitually.  SENATOR TAYLOR stated he just
label: BODY

text: wanted to know approximately.  Stuart Decker said seasonally it
label: BODY

text: is very different.  On June 15 there may be 10, 15, 20 over a
label: BODY

text: course of a 30-mile stretch and you could float that far in a
label: BODY

text: day.  In September, 30 miles of river represents 6 days worth of
label: BODY

text: fishing and there would be between 2 and 4 outfitters on a
label: BODY

text: section.  Anywhere from Divide to Melrose there would be 10 to 12
label: BODY

text: boats being put in at Divide and 10 to go into Melrose.
label: BODY

text: {Tape : 1; Side : B; Approx. Time Counter : 0}
label: HH2

text: SENATOR BISHOP asked if the Big Hole and Beaverhead are the only
label: HH2

text: rivers they are having a problem within his district.  SENATOR
label: BODY

text: SWYSGOOD replied yes.  SENATOR BISHOP asked about the Ruby River
label: HH1

text: and the Madison River.  SENATOR SWYSGOOD said he didn't want to
label: BODY

text: open a can of worms on the Madison and he is not as familiar with
label: BODY

text: that river.  He said it is a whole different situation.
label: BODY

text: Closing by Sponsor:
label: HH2

text: SENATOR CHARLES SWYSGOOD, SD 17, Dillon said he has some real
label: HH2

text: concerns as it relates to the resource and the use of those
label: BODY

text: resources.  He stated maybe everything we do isn't the panacea
label: BODY

text: for trying to correct everything.  He said they see some real
label: BODY

text: potential for devastation of the resource.  He thinks that is why
label: BODY

text: the bill contains the section which allows them to address other
label: BODY

text: uses of the river and allows them to establish a management plan
label: BODY

text: for all recreational uses of the river.  He said when it comes to
label: BODY

text: limiting use on the river by the outfitters, it is a difficult
label: BODY

text: situation to address, but if they do something similar to what is
label: BODY

text: being suggested, then it couldn't get any worse than it is right
label: BODY

text: now.  He stated to remember a fishing outfitter files an
label: BODY

text: operational plan and the outfitter lists the rivers he is going
label: BODY

text: to use.  Any outfitter that has an operational plan on file, as
label: BODY

text: of January 1, 1999 and lists the Beaverhead and the Big Hole,
label: BODY

text: would be part of the total picture.  He has concerns with some of
label: BODY

text: the amendments as to where they are going and the committee will
label: BODY

text: discuss them during executive action.  He said their intent is
label: BODY

text: that the situation has to be rectified or at least slowed down,
label: BODY

text: which the bill is attempting to do.  He hopes when the
label: BODY

text: SENATE COMMITTEE ON FISH AND GAME
label: BODY

text: February 16, 1999
label: BODY

text: PAGE 7 of 21
label: BODY

text: 990216FIS_Sm1.wpd
label: BODY

text: legislature convenes next time there will be a proposal that will
label: BODY

text: be more broad and encompassing to further protect this valuable
label: BODY

text: resource.  He had another concern with the amendment covering the
label: BODY

text: weekends.
label: BODY

text: {Tape : 1; Side : B; Approx. Time Counter : 4.6}
label: HH2

text: HEARING ON SB 458
label: HH3

text: Sponsor:  SENATOR FRED THOMAS, SD 31, Stevensville
label: HH2

text: Proponents:
label: HH2

text: Greg Munther, MT Bowhunters Association
label: BODY

text: Stan Rauch, MT Bowhunters Association
label: BODY

text: Pat Graham, Fish Wildlife and Parks
label: BODY

text: Opponents:
label: HH2

text: None.
label: BODY

text: Opening Statement by Sponsor:
label: HH2

text: SENATOR FRED THOMAS, SD 31, Stevensville said the illegal taking
label: HH2

text: of trophy big game is a serious problem in Montana.  He states
label: BODY

text: SB 458 raises the bar and substantially penalizes a person that
label: BODY

text: would be convicted of purposely knowing or negligently taking,
label: BODY

text: killing or possessing or transporting a trophy animal.  He said
label: BODY

text: one important detail is the common hunter who makes a mistake.
label: BODY

text: This bill has some serious fines for having these animals in
label: BODY

text: their possession or taking them.  He said that is why they built
label: BODY

text: in the language in page 3, line 9, subsection F which states what
label: BODY

text: he read before.  You must be convicted of purposely knowing or
label: BODY

text: negligent.  This is a high bar versus just having or being there.
label: BODY

text: He stated if the language is not satisfactory, then he is for
label: BODY

text: improving it.  He thinks they have accomplished that.
label: BODY

text: He discussed section 1 which set up the significant penalties.
label: BODY

text: He said they want to raise the threshold in Montana to make it a
label: BODY

text: serious penalty to poach and possess game that is illegally
label: BODY

text: taken.  He stated this bill will make Montana a bad place to
label: BODY

text: poach big game and the result of not passing the bill is to say
label: BODY

text: "why not poach here in Montana where the game is good and the
label: BODY

text: penalties are light."
label: BODY

text: Proponents' Testimony:
label: HH2

text: Greg Munther, MT Bowhunters Association, stated the association
label: HH2

text: believes most Montanans intent to be law abiding and are law
label: BODY

text: abiding when it comes to hunting and fishing.  He said there are
label: BODY

text: a number of people in this state who use the wide open spaces and
label: BODY

text: SENATE COMMITTEE ON FISH AND GAME
label: BODY

text: February 16, 1999
label: BODY

text: PAGE 8 of 21
label: BODY

text: 990216FIS_Sm1.wpd
label: BODY

text: the quality of our animals for personal gain either monitarially
label: BODY

text: or for some sort of self gratification in illegally harvesting
label: BODY

text: the biggest and the best of Montana's wildlife.  The association
label: BODY

text: believes Montana will become attractive as surrounding states
label: BODY

text: raise their penalties for similar violations as has happened in
label: BODY

text: Colorado and Utah.  The association would like to urge support of
label: BODY

text: the bill because they believe it would better balance the risks.
label: BODY

text: The reward of being caught and prosecuted in a substantial way
label: BODY

text: serves as an deterrent for those people who might consider such
label: BODY

text: actions.
label: BODY

text: He entered and discussed the informational packet,
label: BODY

text: EXHIBIT(fis38a09).
label: HH1

text: He stated there are three elements the association feel are
label: BODY

text: important.  They believe the restitution amounts should reflect
label: BODY

text: market values.  The second element is a license revocation.  He
label: BODY

text: said this bill proposes that fishing and hunting licenses be
label: BODY

text: revoked for violators who take these trophy animals intentionally
label: BODY

text: for five years as would poaching any big game animal using a
label: BODY

text: spotlight, infrared scope, or night scope.  The association feels
label: BODY

text: these are deliberate acts; there is no mistaking that these
label: BODY

text: animals were killed illegally and maliciously.  The third element
label: BODY

text: is that the money collected from the restitution penalties would
label: BODY

text: be directed back into Montana hunter education programs.  He said
label: BODY

text: the hunter education programs are meant to promote and teach
label: BODY

text: ethical, legal, and responsible hunting behavior which they
label: BODY

text: believe is positive for the State of Montana, especially the
label: BODY

text: sportsmen who are now being cheated.
label: BODY

text: {Tape : 1; Side : B; Approx. Time Counter : 15.1}
label: HH2

text: Stan Rauch, MT Bowhunters Association, discussed the antlers
label: HH2

text: which were brought for demonstration of poached big game in
label: BODY

text: Montana.  He said a lot of poaching comes from people out of
label: BODY

text: state.  They go to the states where penalties are the lightest
label: BODY

text: and take the trophy big game animals and leave.  He said the only
label: BODY

text: way to get people's attention is to promote the much higher
label: BODY

text: fines.
label: BODY

text: Pat Graham, Fish Wildlife and Parks, provided written testimony,
label: HH2

text: EXHIBIT(fis38a10).
label: HH1

text: Opponents' Testimony:  None.
label: HH2

text: Questions from Committee Members and Responses:
label: HH2

text: SENATE COMMITTEE ON FISH AND GAME
label: BODY

text: February 16, 1999

text: 990216FIS_Sm1.wpd
label: BODY

text: SENATOR BECK asked about goats being taken for trophy.  He was
label: HH1

text: shown by a committee member where in the bill it states goats are
label: BODY

text: included.
label: BODY

text: Closing by Sponsor:
label: HH2

text: SENATOR FRED THOMAS, SD 31, Stevensville, stated there is no way
label: HH2

text: we want the mistaken hunter to get hammered.  He wants the
label: BODY

text: committee to be comfortable with the bill that passes out of the
label: BODY

text: committee.  He said it isn't their intent to get someone who made
label: BODY

text: a mistake, they want to hammer the poachers who are making a
label: BODY

text: business of this in Montana.
label: BODY

text: {Tape : 1; Side : B; Approx. Time Counter : 23.1}

text: Opening Statement by Sponsor:
label: HH2

text: SENATOR CHARLES SWYSGOOD, SD 17, Dillon, stated SB 418 is brought
label: HH2

text: to the committee because of the increasing conflicts between
label: BODY

text: landowners and sportsmen regarding the use of bridge easements on
label: BODY

text: county or state roads for access to underlying water courses.  He
label: BODY

text: explained how the Ruby River Task Force was established and what
label: BODY

text: their objectives were.
label: BODY

text: He stated the Department of FWP requested an Attorney General's
label: BODY

text: opinion regarding the issue of recreational access at bridges.
label: BODY

text: The opinion has not been forth coming from the Attorney General.
label: BODY

text: He believes the FWP does not have authority over county roads or
label: BODY

text: county bridges, he thinks they rest with the Department of
label: BODY

text: Transportation and/or the county governments.  The bill is to
label: BODY

text: discuss this issue and to get an open and honest debate so they
label: BODY

text: can make some decisions on what the committee hears in the
label: BODY

text: hearing.  He believes they have some valid arguments as it
label: BODY

text: relates to the use of bridge and road easements for access
label: BODY

text: especially across private property.  He said this legislation
label: BODY

text: does not prevent access from any designated access site, any
label: BODY

text: place where the county or state owns the land adjacent to the
label: BODY

text: water course, any place where the right of way is held in fee
label: BODY

text: title by the county or state, any place where the term of
label: BODY

text: easement specifically allows access or any area where landowners
label: BODY

text: give permission for access.  He said the bill defines the
label: BODY

text: easements on county roads and bridges as it relates to access of
label: BODY

text: where private land is concerned.
label: BODY

text: Proponents' Testimony:
label: HH2

text: Page Dringman, MT Landowners Alliance, entered a pamphlet with
label: HH2

text: access sites and letters from counties, EXHIBIT(fis38a11), and
label: BODY

text: letters from residents who could not be present,
label: BODY

text: EXHIBIT(fis38a12).  Mrs. Dringman stated the bill was requested
label: HH1

text: by FWP for an Attorney General's opinion.  The request was made
label: BODY

text: February 16, 1999

text: in June and no opinion has been forthcoming and landowners have
label: BODY

text: been concerned with the issue.  She said landowners have also
label: BODY

text: been concerned with the FWP request because the FWP asked for a
label: BODY

text: broad right of access that is correlated to the recreational use
label: BODY

text: of streams statutes.  The FWP request to the Attorney General and
label: BODY

text: the landowners' concerns were discussed.
label: BODY

text: Page Dringman said the FWP argument in the memorandum is the
label: BODY

text: public right of recreating in water courses between the high
label: BODY

text: water marks is justification for a right of access.  Mrs.
label: BODY

text: Dringman stated the argument uses the public trust doctrine which
label: BODY

text: has always been a judicial doctrine addressing water born uses as
label: BODY

text: a land use tool to restrict private property rights.  On the
label: BODY

text: stream access law,  the law does not provide a right of access
label: BODY

text: from dry land above the high water mark.
label: BODY

text: Page Dringman also commented on the numerous misrepresentations
label: BODY

text: in the newspapers and the testimony given by the sponsor.  She
label: BODY

text: said the bill does not prohibit access where there is public land
label: BODY

text: or where there the road or bridge is held in fee by the county or
label: BODY

text: state.
label: BODY

text: The pamphlet was explained and handed in the Montana Afloat map,
label: BODY

text: EXHIBIT(fis38a13).  Mrs. Dringman said the issue before the
label: HH1

text: committee concerns the scope of the easement that was given to
label: BODY

text: the county or the state Department of Transportation.  She
label: BODY

text: commented on court cases that have determined the scope of the
label: BODY

text: easement and on bills in the current legislature.  She also
label: BODY

text: commented on the noxious weed bill and how noxious weeds are
label: BODY

text: being spread and prevention of spread.
label: BODY

text: Page Dringman clarified that private property rights are a
label: BODY

text: fundamental right; there are constitutionally protected rights
label: BODY

text: and it has to be balanced with the right of recreation.  She
label: BODY

text: mentioned the court case of Garrison v Avral.  Comments on the
label: BODY

text: environmental degradation and stream bank erosion were
label: BODY

text: considered.  On her talk with the Department of Transportation,
label: BODY

text: they don't believe their highway easements for the highway
label: BODY

text: purpose encompasses recreational use.  Letters from the counties
label: BODY

text: were discussed.
label: BODY

text: Page Dringman stated the passage of SB 418 doesn't prevent
label: BODY

text: fishing access site acquisition and negotiations but does say we
label: BODY

text: recognize a difference between an easement and fee title.

label: BODY

label: HH2

text: support SB 418.  She stated wife policy specifically recognizes
label: BODY

text: the importance of guarding private property rights of landowners.
label: BODY

text: She reminded the committee the law established in Montana is the
label: BODY

text: extent of the servitude is determined by the terms under which it
label: BODY

text: was originally granted.

text: Debby Barrett, self, said she looked in the Constitution and
label: HH2

text: could not find recreational, sportsmen's or fishing rights.  She

text: Jerry Wells, MT Council of Trout Unlimited, said the preamble of
label: HH2

text: the bill suggests that the current uses at bridges are a new
label: BODY

text: phenomenon and he suggests that is not the case.  He stated
label: BODY

text: public right of way easements at bridges have been used for
label: BODY

text: putting in and taking out boats for fishermen to gain access to
label: BODY

text: streams for a long time.  He explained why the majority of the
label: BODY

text: right of way acquisitions in fee are easements.  He said in
label: BODY

text: acquiring the easements the state paid the full market value of
label: BODY

text: the fee value even though they were only getting an easement.  He
label: BODY

text: understood they did that to gain as much possessory right as they
label: BODY

text: could get.  He said today the right of ways are used for a wide
label: BODY

text: range of uses and list various uses.  He said many of the smaller
label: BODY

text: rivers and streams have seen landowner changes which have
label: BODY

text: resulted where once there was access and now wealthy nonresidents
label: BODY

text: own the land and are keeping everybody out.
label: BODY

text: He said the impact of passing SB 418 will eliminate access for
label: BODY

text: people.  He believes SB 418 is an extreme solution to what ever
label: BODY

text: problems do exist at individual sites.  He commented on the Wolf
label: BODY

text: Creek bridge site on the Missouri River.  He commented on lines
label: BODY

text: Jim McDermand, Organizations United for Rivers & Streams, written
label: HH2

text: testimony, EXHIBIT(fis38a20).

text: Stan Bradshaw, self, said he was involved with the stream access
label: HH2

text: cases when heard before the Supreme Court.  He also assisted in

text: the drafting of the legislation of the current stream access
label: BODY

text: bill.  He does not think SB 418 is the appropriate way to address

text: the concern of the landowners.  He commented on the memorandum
label: BODY

text: for the Attorney General and the people who have opposed the
label: BODY

text: position that has been expressed by OURS.  He said if the bill
label: BODY

text: was a clarification bill then the Attorney General will come to

text: the conclusion he cannot make law.  He said if the bill passes,

text: then the opportunity is forth closed to consider the legitimate

text: concerns of the recreationalists.

text: Ruby River Task Force and its accomplishments.  He said they did
label: BODY

text: have opposition by wealthy out-of-state new age landowners.  The

text: wealthy landowners could not restrict access and no longer market

text: Montana public resource as an exclusive property right.  He

label: BODY

text: back by the wealthy landowners.

text: He believes true sportsmen would never side with the trespassing,
label: BODY

text: with the littering, the abuses and language and believes there
label: BODY

text: are laws that deal with these problems.  It seems to him the
label: BODY

text: right of way at bridges has only become a problem in the age of
label: BODY

text: the new age landowner.  He believes the bill is to add value to
label: BODY

text: their property by taking a public resource and making a private
label: BODY

text: property right.  He said the bill would deal away public property
label: BODY

text: rights for the benefit of private ownership without any
label: BODY

text: compensation back to the public.  He said these people are
label: BODY

text: selling Montana's fisheries for big money and the public gets no
label: BODY

text: money for that.  He said this is a taking in reverse.  He said if
label: BODY

text: SB 418 is passed, many citizens will lose a vital component
label: BODY

text: essential to the way of life in Montana for the benefit of a
label: BODY

text: select few.

text: SENATOR BECK referred to the map given by Mr. Holden.  He said he
label: HH2

text: sees where he is putting the boats in.  He asked where is he
label: BODY

text: parking his vehicle.  Bill Holden replied in the ditch up and
label: BODY

text: down the side.  There is public land along the road, you have to
label: BODY

text: use the ditch.  SENATOR BECK asked if there is room.  Mr. Holden
label: BODY

text: responded generally.  SENATOR BECK stated he thinks here are
label: BODY

text: problems on all bridges and there are some bridges that should be
label: BODY

text: access sites but may not all bridges.  In the drawing by Mr.
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: He hasn't seen anybody park a boat next to the access.

label: HH1

text: related to CI-75 have consumed them over the last couple of

text: months.  SENATOR DOHERTY said there has been a suggestion that a

label: BODY

text: said the FWP did address through some easements and fee title
label: BODY

text: acquisitions, property along the Ruby River.  He said one of the

text: recommendations of the Task Force was to clarify the issue

text: through the opinion.

text: prohibits, but easements usually don't expressly prohibit, they
label: BODY

text: say what use maybe made of the easement.  SENATOR BISHOP referred
label: BODY

text: to line 20, page 2, number 3.  He asked if the legislature is
label: BODY

text: powerful enough to take property away or give it away.  He asked
label: BODY

text: if the bridge is 40 feet wide and the right of way is 60 feet
label: BODY

text: wide.  Mrs. Dringman replied if there is an existing easement
label: BODY

text: that specifies the width of the right at the bridge then that
label: BODY

text: document should control, so, if that is unclear then the bill
label: BODY

text: could be amended to address that.  She said this came about
label: BODY

text: because the existing statutes say the width of all county roads
label: BODY

text: except bridges, alleys and lanes must be 60 feet.  She said the
label: BODY

text: Department of Transportation and county's concerns is if they
label: BODY

text: will be able to maintain the underlying structures but often the
label: BODY

text: bridge easement doesn't specify.
label: BODY

text: SENATOR BECK asked Mr. Graham what kind of ruling are they asking
label: HH2

text: for from the Attorney General.  Pat Graham said the chief legal
label: BODY

text: council was present who prepared the request and he could answer
label: BODY

text: the question.  Bob Lane said they asked for a ruling for a number
label: BODY

text: of reasons dealing with what they felt was a growing controversy.
label: BODY

text: He said the request was for an opinion about access at road
label: BODY

text: right-of-ways to cross rivers or streams.  They realized an
label: BODY

text: answer would not solve all of the circumstances but felt many of
label: BODY

text: them could be answered with his opinion based on case law and the
label: BODY

text: Constitution.  They asked the Attorney General to answer as much
label: BODY

text: as he felt he could about access at bridge crossings.
label: BODY

text: SENATOR BECK asked if they included interstates, secondary roads,
label: HH2

text: primary roads, not just county roads.  Bob Lane responded he
label: BODY

text: believes they asked for access at county roads but the same
label: BODY

text: principles would apply also to state right-of-ways.  He said
label: BODY

text: essentially they were dealing with issues along the Ruby River
label: BODY

text: and county roads there.  SENATOR BECK asked if it was strictly
label: BODY

text: for county roads.
label: BODY

text: SENATOR MESAROS stated if Mr. Lane could submit information of
label: HH2

text: the request to the committee it would be helpful.
label: BODY

text: SENATOR TAYLOR said there is a concern with the public's lack of
label: HH2

text: respect for property rights as mentioned by the people.  He asked
label: BODY

text: how should the issue be addressed about the concerns of these
label: BODY

text: people.  Mr. Lane said it is both the legal and a policy
label: BODY

text: question.  The FWP does acknowledge the problems.  He thinks they
label: BODY

text: can be handled by prosecutions for trespass or littering.  He
label: BODY

text: thinks they can be handled by some restrictions on access.  He
label: BODY

text: said they recognize that there are police powers to the state
label: BODY

text: that can control that and set limits on it.
label: BODY

text: SENATOR MESAROS stated he would like a copy of the request
label: HH1

text: submitted to the committee.  He said there is a big difference
label: BODY

text: between county roads and interstate.  He said in his district
label: BODY

text: there is a state highway and county roads going through private
label: BODY

text: property and neither which a right of way has ever been
label: BODY

text: purchased.  He said there is a lot of variation between means of
label: BODY

text: acquiring right of ways for public roads.
label: BODY

text: Bob Lane said the question they asked was "may a member of the
label: HH2

text: recreating public gain access from the right of way of a public
label: BODY

text: road at a bridge crossing to a stream or river between the
label: BODY

text: ordinary high water marks.  He said their question was broad from
label: BODY

text: a public road which could include state roads or county roads.
label: BODY

text: He recognized one opinion will not solve all problems.
label: BODY

text: Closing by Sponsor:
label: HH2

text: {Tape : 3; Side : A; Approx. Time Counter : 0}
label: HH2

text: SENATOR CHARLES SWYSGOOD, SD 17, Dillon, said he thinks the issue
label: HH2

text: was brought to the committee for a good reason.  He said the
label: BODY

text: Attorney General has had the request for 8 months and has not
label: BODY

text: rendered a decision.  He doesn't know if an answer is coming.  He
label: BODY

text: said he doesn't know it says anywhere that the legislature can't
label: BODY

text: bring forth an issue to be discussed and be decided by the body
label: BODY

text: as it relates to anything they do.  He said it would be nice to
label: BODY

text: have an answer and that is what the bill attempts to do.  He
label: BODY

text: stated the role of the FWP is to manage wildlife and fish for the
label: BODY

text: recreating public and for the public well being, and to provide
label: BODY

text: recreation opportunities for all Montanans.  He wonders if that
label: BODY

text: means expanding a definition or a use, such as an easement to fit
label: BODY

text: that purpose, that is what the committee is going to decide.  He
label: BODY

text: said in most incidents there isn't much management that is a
label: BODY

text: responsibility of the FWP at many of the bridge sites unless it
label: BODY

text: is a specified access site.
label: BODY

text: He doesn't think the committee, by passing the judicial
label: BODY

text: authority, is addressing the concerns that the bill brings
label: BODY

text: forward.  He commented about the question the FWP asked the
label: BODY

text: Attorney General.
label: BODY

text: He said county roads are where the problem exists.  He said some
label: BODY

text: road right of way, particularly state highways, are mostly held
label: BODY

text: in fee title however the interest held in most road right-of-ways
label: BODY

text: particularly county roads are an easement, not fee title.
label: BODY

text: He read  section 7, 142107.  He said the ownership of the
label: BODY

text: easement interest rather than the fee title limits and restricts
label: BODY

text: appropriate use of public road right-of-ways.  He commented there
label: BODY

text: are a variety of ways in which a road can be created and to
label: BODY

text: 990216FIS_Sm1.wpd
label: BODY

text: determine the width for any easement or fee.  He referred to
label: BODY

text: section 1822.  He commented with a road established by petition
label: BODY

text: or grant, which most county roads are, are governed by the
label: BODY

text: designated width with the petition or the grant.  He said usually
label: BODY

text: the right of ways established by subscription are only as wide as
label: BODY

text: the prescriptive use that established that road.
label: BODY

text: He said the whole premise of the FWP's memorandum is premised
label: BODY

text: that the public has a Constitutional right to access.  He said
label: BODY

text: the public doesn't have a Constitutional right to access, they
label: BODY

text: have a Constitutional right to use the waters.  He said there is
label: BODY

text: no guarantee exists to the access to the waters.
